summary: This animated tale follows the relationship between the small human-like Oms and their much larger blue-skinned oppressors, the Draags, who rule the planet of Ygam. While the Draags have long kept Oms as illiterate pets, this hierarchy shifts after an Om boy becomes educated, thanks to a young female Draag. This leads to an Om rebellion, which weakens the Draag control over their race. Will the Oms and the Draags find a way to coexist? Or will they destroy each other?

reviews.content: Must be downloaded from another reality🥹

Vivid, imaginative, trippy and thought-provoking. Can't do anything except gawking the screen, wide-eyed the entire time. Such inventive and ingenious piece of art. One of the most profound films I've ever seen.
A fantastic story with brilliant animation, this is 100% worth a watch. Even if i can't call it perfect just because of my views on the characters. But a good 90/100 is fantastic enough for me.

Admittedly, it's a rather bizarre film but truly fantastic. The animation style is differently unique and successfully adds to the imaginative story of this world. It is a sweet film that is an absolutely pleasure to watch.

What an intriguing and interesting movie. I definitely need to give this another watch in the future to fully grasp the themes of this movie. Despite the fact that I didn't fully understand everything about this movie, I can't ignore the incredible storytelling and animation. The concept of a higher life form living amongst human "Oms" is very interesting. Seeing these higher life forms treating humans like ants is fascinating to watch. The story is very engaging and keeps you locked in the whole time. It's paced to perfection and has a run time of only an hour and twelve minutes. The animation is very unique and cool to look at. Overall, it's a very unique and fascinating animated movie to watch that gets you thinking.
I LOVED this film, the music, art style, and storyline was amazing in my opinion, It was very weird in the best way possible.

One of the greatest films of all time in my opinion. Campiness that truly surprises with its depth. And then you realize that it's not really that camp at all, it's just a genuinely beautiful movie with really really cool animation.
love it, great visually and music.
A very artistic and surreal science fiction film about human and animal rights.

This is what happens when you drop acid while making a movie.  This movie makes no sense and fails to answer the most basic questions.  Like, is this Earth?  Did they take the humans off Earth?  How did they take over humanity?  How long ago was it?  It seems like generations to a point of humans regressing.  So one human figuring out the aliens tech is like Nova from "the Planet of the Apes" figure out how a gun works.  Being psychedelic is no excuse for not having proper story structure.  "Yellow Submarine" was very psychedelic but you can follow the story.  This movie never bothers to explain anything.  None of the characters had any real development and like every French movie I've seen so far it's slow.  This one darn right boring.  Say no to drugs when making movies and there's a difference between art and "ART!".
I know this is a Criterion Collection but it's just so *Weird*, I cannot say if I really liked it thus my average of 3 stars!!!
Weird - and Blobbo normally like weird - but emotionally vacant in a '60's, European kind of way.
This movie features beautiful illustrations. It's fun to just watch parts of it to enjoy the drawings. But I didn't find the plot particularly compelling.
I saw this on Nightflight in the 80s and was immediately hooked.  I owned the dvd for years and it was in both English and French.  Both gorgeous and surreal.

This is a masterpiece integrating concepts of Hinduism and the Jiva (here as Tiwa). There's a cosmic interest intertwining India and France here, as homme (Man) is turned into OM.

Are the blue people more evolved than the human slaves? Yes. Of course. Certainly in how the blues have sexual intercourse. The correct alien practice of such tantra is shown here, which is why the humans are a lower life form, and are treated as pets.

Everyone can get along, however. If you overhear Tiwa's radio station (as the result of a Yogic and/or other spiritual manifestations), it's a hard class to take, but worthwhile for the sake of discontinuing your own suffering.
this shows that animation is not a crutch to sell jokes but rather a medium to tell a story
Hypnotic, brilliant.... and a little bit terrifying.

Clearly in the minority, I found Fantastic Planet to be less than engaging.  The story is pretty straight-forward – the planet Ygam is ruled by the Draags, a race of ruby-eyed blue giants, who rule over the Oms, thought by the Draags to be an inferior species with minimal intelligence.  As the table turns in the latter portions of the film, it appears to become a Cold War parable, emphasizing the importance of the two powers learning to live together in peace. While some of the animation is fantastic, much of it seems static.  In addition, the characters seem underdeveloped and the whole thing just felt a bit slight.

Distinctively designed and immediately recognizable, Fantastic Planet has essentially become the poster child for arthouse animation. Evoking a much earlier style but adding a fluidity that predecessors may have lacked, the film has a somewhat thematically simple narrative but thrives off of worldbuilding and creative detail, allowing viewers to take in an almost retrofuturistic take on science fiction. If there's a major criticism, it's the structure of the conflict between the film's two factions, which never seems to instill the gravitas in its combatants or the atmosphere as a whole that it likely should, though this may be due in part to the film's muted tone, again a throwback to earlier years. One of those films that you might have to go out of your way to watch, but one that everyone should see at least once. (3.5/5)
Fantastic imagination! It's like something Heironymous Bosch and Terry Gilliam would cook up together. The film's vivid other-worldly images endure more than the story and script.

Wow, the sound in this movie is on a whole other level. It's impressive how much detail was put into it. The music is like a main character. This is so fucking trippy! Wtf?! So fucking weird and creepy. These aliens are so advanced that we humans are just play things to them. Almost like pets. I can't imagine living in a world like that where everything is so unknown. It'd be a nightmare. It's interesting to see how the Draags live and how they do their daily rituals like meditating and eating and learning and even getting high with friends. 

Hmm. Interesting. The humans, or Oms in this world, are more savage than the Draags. I guess this is social commentary on our society and how we are as humans and how we need to evolve ourselves and reach a higher level of consciousness. It's also a social commentary on social classes - rich vs. poor. Pretty frightening some of the things that happen in this movie. It wasn't until the Oms started fucking with the way of living and their rituals, that the Draags decided to let them have their own satellite so they could live in peace. This movie teaches us that we must learn to coexist with one another no matter our backgrounds, skin color, ideology or whether rich or poor. 

Man, the music is so fucking good. Funky, groovy, haunting and eerie but also ethereal and otherworldly. It basically creates the whole vibe of the movie. The art style is very unique. The concepts for all the different creatures and plant life are very inventive and creative. Unlike any other movie out there, this movie stands on its own. Fantastic! I must own it
Weird and incredibly, an amazing psychological look at social and class relations.

Not a fan of surrealism, but the film works well regardless.
An allegorical take on superiority fueled racism and oppression (up to a Holocaust-like annihilation schemes).
I liked this movie when I was a kid.  While the animation remains impressive, I find the story pretty lame now.

A very unique curiosity, both in animation style and storywise. The idea of humans living in a world were we are not the top of the food chain is fresh. Sadly this movie falls short for me in part because of how music is not as imaginative as the visuals, it sounds like a porn movie from the 70s.

Animation remind me that of Terry Gilliam

A dystopian surreal animated epic that's sometimes fascinating and others disturbing, but it's incredible to look at, it has stylish and beautiful visuals, and plenty of social commentary. A must watch for film enthusiasts although not recommended to watch when depressed nor influenced by drugs.

Engaging animated film about a planet, Yaag (?) where gigantic creatures called Draags are dominant while humans, known as Ons, are barely the size of insects. The Oms are either living in the wild or are tamed as pets to the Draag. One Draag, Tiwa, allows her pet Om, Terr, to become educated - which then leads to unintended consequences. The animation is really more stop action comics, yet the fantastic world and the creatures that populated it are like some trippy cartoons of the 1970's. Interesting and worth seeing.

The world building of the planet Ygam is absolutely... fantastic! The more the film advances, the more I get to audiovisually explore this unique world, and consequently the more I became surprised every time I encounter an otherworldly technological invention that has been always in my head since my childhood, hoping they'd be realized someday. So, it's clear that watching this proved a fulfilling experience in regards of this aspect.

On the other hand, I can't say the same about exploring the premise of the film itself. Being in the animals' place and controlled by even more superior creatures is a concept that also has been in my head (probably because I encountered a lot of stray and abused animals when I was young), but this film didn't expand upon this idea enough to go beyond what I thought about. The only thing that I think redeemed Fantastic Planet in this aspect is that the facial expressions of the human characters (or should I say Oms) are uniquely and effortlessly expressive of how they perceive the treatment of the Draags which, in turn, reflect how we'd feel if we were put in the animals' place. But then again, this also is attributable to the technical competence of the crew, especially the animators. That's what I thought about the film until I realized I was only halfway through.

Although it's still a bit of a let down for me, what really saved this from being a huge disappointment is the depth of the subtext. It's not until the second half that the plot begins to unravel. Here we finally find out that the surreal, hallucinatory imagery has in fact a surprising depth. Here the story finally begins to consider the Oms, enslaved, humiliated, helpless and inferior as they are, are human beings after all. Without going to any further detail to avoid spoiling anything, but this film tackles speciesism and social discrimination like no other film did. It's just a shame that it takes too long to establish its world building before getting into its message. As a result, anyone could easily mistake the film for being superficial watching only its overstretched first half, and as a consequence, the second half is too condensed for its own good, given how rich it is.

(7.5/10)
It is nice to see how humans really are. A binary twist of truth that we all should apply to real living beings.
This animated film is quite imaginative, but the ending is too primitive for the task it undertook, it mars the whole impression of the movie, which otherwise is quite remarkable visually.

"Fantastic Planet" is a movie more than a commentary about politics but more an absurd picture of ourselves about humans. Apart from no character development or any character study, this movie lets you think further. There are so many other weird things besides focusing on the Oms and the Draags. It's weird but very relevant to the current era. Truly, this movie earns its way adjectively.
A fantastic surreal adventure through a truly alien world.
Strange and dreamlike, Fantastic Planet is a quiet dystopian vision that feels dated but is nonetheless intriguing and at times disturbing.

Terrifying and yet poetic "Fantastic World" is way more credible than many religions out there, and it teaches us a lesson that many religions out there teach us, and it does so in just over an hour. So doesn't really matter what is your belief or if like me you have none, you should watch this Dalinian fable and enjoy every creative detail.

If I were putting together a Cartoon Movie Top 10, this would make the cut. It's whimsical and weird. Surreal, yet coherent. It evokes a truly alien existence. Unfortunately the underdog 'how would you like it!' trope is in full force in this film which sees humans enslaved by a more powerful species. Trust me, it's been done to death. Christ, that sort of on-the-nose topsy turvy 'what if' fantasy goes back to Gulliver's Travels and was already a dead horse lain for the beating when Fritz made Metropolis. It really reeks of the sort of shallow thinking agenda pushing which was quintessential of Marxist Eurotrash all through the 60's and into the late 80's. 

Alas this film is pure 70's. The good weird 70's which is still good and weird now and the anachronisms and cliches which polluted that decade's art. Yeah, yeah, the film's as thought-provoking as a lava lamp but in terms of  pure charm, innovation and artistry, I would have given it 5 stars.

Surreal and creatively F A N T A S T I C.
René Laloux, 1973
Animated sci-fi.

Unique animated French film about a planet where two separate alien species (One exploitative of the other miniature human-like race) learn to somehow co-exist. Surrelist and idiosyncratic with wonderfully trippy animation, La Planete Sauvage is an intelligent, philosophical experience that presents a universal perspective on the folly of the human race.
Fantastic Planet is very good. Very unique and cute movie that anyone would like
Not as revelatory in the art or story as one would hope, but if you want a strange way to spend an hour it's not a bad choice.
It's Terry Gilliam's animation style married with an acid trip.  Truly surreal, engrossing, and worthy of it's Cannes film festival prize.

Known futuristic animation with a surreal and creative story, looks and presentation. The animation production started in Prague but was moved to Paris shortly after. Done in French - the language I used too. Not sure if a dubbed version would have lifted it or not.

Blue giants, known as "Draags" are ruling a planet and they take some human-ish creatures, known as "Oms" as slaves or pets or something. The Oms tries to get their freedom and there is a war going on between the two species. Who will win?

This film is all about letting your mind go and observe and digest the images. It's beautifully crafted. Great drawings, sweet creatures and imaginative like drugs where a must at the production and the result is an actual drug itself. For me the best part of the film was still the soundtrack done by Alain Goraguer. Trippy, soulful jazz - almost like triphop at times. Songs from this film has been sampled by loads of artists and it's easy to see (hear) why. The combination of dope music and extraordinary, sci-fi animation is superb - but even if the story is good too, I wanted even more. I missed some character development or some feelings towards a few characters. I felt like an observer, observing an entire society. 

It's all right, but it feels like I missed out on many details that way and my attention fell at times. Still I would not have the lenght expanded. 70 minutes felt about right. I'm sure there is plenty of symbolism and metaphores here, but I don't get half of it. Fascinating, trippy, memorable and psychedelic film that's both disturbing and touching.

8 out of 10 rain cloud producing gadgets.
Unique animated French film about a planet where two separate alien species (One exploitative of the other miniature human-like race) learn to somehow co-exist.

I watched Fantastic Planet for the first time about a week ago and it is still seeping greatly through my psyche. I don't think I'd ever experienced a film that shattered my perception of reality so strongly and with profound philosophical intent, creatively integrating Plato's allegory, theory of mind, and lots of Nietzschean existentialism. It is a social statement along with a statement on our consciousness told through beautifully demented sci-fi dystopia. An absolute masterpiece.
Very trippy and interesting!
Extremely weird and intriguing commentary on one species domination over another. The trippy Bosch/Dalí animation coupled with the art rock soundtrack makes this film a fun watch.
One of the standout unique animation movies, made on a limited budget and with imagination from a far. Liberal and psychedelic, thus vital in the surival one spieces from an other.
A wholly original film with a unique animation style. The story is interesting but it is the atmosphere and fantasy that truly won me over.
3.5/5 Fantastic Planet delights with surreal visuals and a groovy soundtrack, but the storytelling itself might feel a bit flat to some.
Fantastic Planet is a bizarre, beautiful, imaginative, elegant work of animation.
This bizarre animated sci fi film is a little treasure with its ethical and philosophical issues as a plus.

This animated 1970s French film is highly creative but emotionally empty. Watch it if you want a short (60 min.) dose of psychedelic stop-motion animation, replete with imaginative alien species and a glimpse at humanity gone caveman. While the oppressed people group motif makes for interesting cinema, here it falls short due to its underdeveloped social dynamics. How does the protagonist feel about the Draags or his master in particular? Is he fully accepted by the other Oms? These depths are never explored. Instead, the storyline plods along, skipping a few plot points along the way, and then ends abruptly. The themes change abruptly too, moving from Bildungsroman to the cliché "oppressed people group fighting against oppressors" motif. Even the protagonists' role changes midway as he himself becomes irrelevant to the plot. If the audience cared about him by this point, they would be wondering what happened to him-we're never told-but alas, the plotline is so flat, the emotion so sparse, that the audience hardly connects with him. The other Oms barely seem to connect with him either, for that matter. In short, watch it if you're looking for a memorable merge between fantastical sci-fi and stop-motion animation. If you want a glimpse at human complexity, look elsewhere.

Although simplistic in its allegorical musings on the nature of social class, Fantastic Planet has enough visually psychedelic moments of weirdness to make it an amusing, albeit slight, piece of animated filmmaking.
"Fantastic Planet" is fantastic.
Great especially in an altered state of consciousness.
Neat and surreal film.

Fantastic Planet is a creative and mesmerizing take on a world where human traits are simplified to their basics, and colourful animation is used to convey multiple layers of stories and ideas. It is no surprise this graceful and surreal take on human interactions is french made. Requiring some patience, this animation holds ransom many ideas ready to be taken with proper viewing. Filled with irony and subtle dark humour, there is plenty to be received from Fantastic Planet, a great unexpected find.
Very abstract and surreal. Amazing pen work that complimented the skeletal, haunting stop motion. Great French practice, i understood about half the lines!

This is an utterly strange movie, but also quite intriguing. A glimpse into a completely alien world through the eyes of an outsider - a human. Fascinating."Fantastic Planet" is on a planet of its own. It's a surreal sci-fi trip, Man!!!

A silly and sterile animation that believes to be much smarter than it is (even the wordplays Oms and Terr are obvious), not to mention that it is visually and audibly dated (the music is awful) and constantly loses focus with too much unnecessary detailing about the wild life in Ygam.

A thing a say about all stories and art is "anything can be done right". So if you ask me "Do you know a good European arty science fiction film that treats science with Alice in Wonderland logic?", I point to this masterpiece.

Extremely slow even for a movie lasting just over a hour, this just dragged on and on! Fantastic Planet's only strength is its stylistic, surreal, animation. The characters are boring the story is a bit neat though the novelty wears off quickly, the film definitely shows its age. The movie requires a specific audience because its not for me.

The movie poster for this movie really stood out and I felt as though it would be very interesting. If you don't already know, cutout animation is a technique for producing animations using flat character, props and background cut from material such as paper, card, stiff fabric or even photographs. 
	This really gave Fantastic Planet a unique look, even though it limited the range of motion for the characters and it ability to show range of emotion. From my first go around at watching this movie, I found myself not really listening to the story line, as I was really drawn in by the drawing of the characters and the landscapes that were done. My first responds to this movie was that the creator where on something and couldn't really fathom what they had made.
However the second attempt, made it more clear to me that this movie in my view was pretty much about  two opposing element fighting for control which target the human needs for destruction and inslavement. The animation in fantastic Planet made this message of the need for destruction and inslavement mor digestable by taking us to a faraway planet where blue giants rule, and oppressed humanoids rebel against the machine-like leaders. Pretty much taking a old idea and putting in a new perspective and I believe, had the creature of Fantastic Planet went any other way, other than cutout stop motion, would not given m
e the same experience.
With simple, but nice animation, it's a tought-provoking and entertaining film.

Some cool designs but in world building, characterization, metaphorical inventiveness, and as SF allegory it was about 50 years behind the field. For trippy world building, check out Stanley G. Weinbaum's 1934 story "A Martian Odyssey." For much earlier strong, if equally labored, SF allegory in film, check out Fritz Lang  and Thea von Harbou's "Metropolis."
One of my favorite movies from my youth. The soundtrack is bizarre, the dialogue interesting and the move fascinating. A must see when you are in the mood for oddity.
One of the best animated films of all time

My thoughts are somewhat scattered from my viewing ofÂ Fantastic Planet, the film starts off suave as hell with the electronic score and the opening film title:

Le PlanÃ¨te Sauvage

In this fanastic (or wild plaent, going by direct translation) blue intellectual faints rule over humans. Similar to human interaction with animals, some of the giants consider the humans pests (although acklonledging their high organizational skills), while some of these humans are kept as pets with collars and getting dressed up in ridiculous clothing. While this is just a micro allusion that the film makes, there's a lot of greater symbolism.

The two main themes I reached were oppression (through political systems) and knowledge (which is a tool to fight oppression). It's hard to say which system each life of our protagonist represent. When Terr was kept as a pet to the blue giants, he's like an object of the state. When the domesticated Terr goes into the wild, he joins a more communal system, but which still adores and relies on it's leaders. While it feels that the film is pointing towards the cold war in it's symbolism- space ships representing the scientific exploration for example- it's hard to make a distinction creating a capitalistic and communistic system. Perhaps the film shows they're closer to the same than they're given credit for. Regardless in both systems knowledge brings power, and in both systems it's oppressed.

The animation is very stoic, often leaving lots of blank space, and rarely fluid. There are many great "sanpshots" in the film, often showing creativity, and the images our interesting. But I can't say I'm overly impressed by the animation itself, simply since I've seen more appealing.

The film left me somewhat unaffected, it has some thought provoking spiritual and political under tones, but nothing that lasted.Â
Surreal movie with a great theme and marvelous, mesmerizing music!
What a futuristic view of what life to come when humans living with alien?

Seriously ?  Are you kidding ?  This movie is total junk.  What was the theme ?  What was it about ?  did I need more acid to watch it and then I'd appreciate it?  Am I going against the intellect here ? A serious case of WTF
Surreal and psychedelic with its philantropic idealism, an animation worthy of its epic appraisals.

Winner of a Special Award at the 1973 Cannes Film Festival, this well-intentioned French animated film has not aged well.  Like Zardoz, released the same year, it reeks of the psychedelic drug culture while colliding with the era's New Wave of science fiction,  Like Yellow Submarine, it's more a cultural artifact.
Great visuals, interesting story. Quite futuristic, especially for its time. Highly recommend for sci fi enthusiasts.
This movie is so weird.

An interesting SF story rendered in a unique visual style that is only let down by its over-rushed final act. This is still a must-see for fans of hand-drawn animation and visionary cinema all the same.
Inspired but rudimentary animation; tackles heavy themes and does not pull punches.
Great movie and surprisingly has a lot in common with Prometheus.
Almost as bad as "The Apple."

A strange film that I just could not get into. Then, I did not know anything about the intentions of Fantastic Planet's creators. Was this film a science fiction tale, or an allegory for some other issues on the boil during the era it was made?
Everything about this film suggests that the creators were high when they wrote fantastic planet. It wouldn't be a film I'd run to watch again.

Fantastic Planet is one of those movies that is a treasure unto itself. From the style of animation and design to the awesome soundtrack, it remains a shining achievement for anyone looking for a unique cinematic experience.

Fantastic Planet is a strange and wonderful pioneering animated feature; though its underlying themes are less than subtle, the stark and surrealist imagery is both bleak and hopeful, and it is a vastly original sci-fi vision.

A film set on a faraway planet where giant aliens live, oppressed smaller humanoids rebel against their machine-like leaders. Feels much deeper than the average science fiction animation feature from the psychedelic construction of its environment to the particular style of animation that portrays an original visual concept. Themes of oppression and intolerance add depth and contribute in making this a rewarding watch.
Amazing animation. The story still keeps it's original futuristic enchantment.The ideas conveyed on this movie could be also associated with my long meditational hours in front of my ipad.

A grand tale of humanity's strength as a people and the will to not only survive, but to conquer and defeat its oppressors. Quirky animation and a fantastic soundtrack, this movie should be made into a live action film, but at the same time... it really, REALLY shouldn't.
It resembles too much the "Tripod" trilogy written by John Christopher.
What a mind trip! very psychedelic and creative.
Great sci-fi, oozing with meaning. Cool soundtrack, too, very funky and almost sounded like it would be a great fit for a porn film at times!
Very groovy animation, an original idea, awesome story!
all I could say after I saw this is "what the Fuck did I just watch"
An excellent and very realistic animated film, to represent racism and cruelty, including the ignorance.
Fantastic Planet is visually interesting but dull.
A wonderful animated movie with such a mesmerizing story.
animated oddness you have to be in the mood for.
A very artistic and cultural film.

In the distant future, humankind-now called the Ohm-struggle to live on a primitive planet dominated by an alien race known as the Draag.  After losing his mother to the aliens and being taken in by a Draag named Tiva, Terr adjusts to life as a pet under the roof of Tiva.  Years go by, Terr becomes more mature, and begins to gain knowledge that is unbeknownst to the rest of the surviving Ohm.  As Terr grows older, he escapes with a headset device that contains all of this knowledge and plans to distribute it to the surviving Ohm colonies.  As this is done, the Draag plan to exterminate the Ohm and it becomes up to the humans to fight back.

     Being based on a novel by Stefan Wul and one of the three feature films directed by Rene Laloux, Fantastic Planet (Le Planete Sauvage) is a surreal, imaginative, and fantastic movie that does animated films of its genre much justice.  The story is mostly a political satire about social classes, class warfare, tyranny, and oppression.  Most people may notice that it bears an uncanny resemblance to stories like Battlefield Earth and The Borrowers.  Although, this book and movie came out before L. Ron Hubbard's Battlefield Earth, but the book was written in 1957.  Making it five years after Mary Norton's The Borrowers (1952).  

     The imagery and animation style was produced in France and Czechoslovakia.  It is gorgeous, innovative, and surreal.  A lot of it reminds me of the Terry Gilliam animated segments in Monty Python and the Holy Grail.  Although, the style in which it is used does a superb job at creating a dark atmosphere for the story and conveying its symbolism.  The attention to detail is very well done and the designs of the aliens are great. 

     Most of the story is told through narration and inter-monologue of the main character, Terr.  The dialogue in the film is very well written and is one of those foreign animated films that is good either dubbed or subtitled.  The voice acting in this film is very top notch.  The characters all do a great job at conveying their personalities and give the viewer a sense of life.  

     The music is also very great.  It consists of orchestrated piano music that is very memorable.  It also does a lot in benefiting the surreal and dark tone that is presented in the movie.

     Overall, Fantastic Planet is a superbly directed, animated, and written movie that is enough to please any fan of sci-fi/fantasy animation.  This is a movie that I would recommend any fan of anime or Heavy Metal to watch.  This is one of those Western animated films that people like me love, but just don't see enough of from the West.  Laloux directed two other films like this one: Gandahar/ Light Years and Time Masters.  Neither of which I've seen, but after having seen this movie I'll be looking forward to that time.

The Terry Gilliam-esque animation is very trippy and goes along with the creepy surreal sci-fi settings nicely. The best part of the film is witnessing the creativity of the animators through the wacky unusual creatures and sci-fi aesthetics. One of my favorite moments was a scene where a weird bat-like creature attacks the human colony and the humans have to take it down. The film also has a tasty avant-garde soundtrack that adds to the surreal vibe of the film. 

This film was originally released on a double bill with 'Yellow Submarine', which was another counterculture film released under the guise of a children film. The plot boils down to a 'Planet of the Apes'-like story with a thinly-veiled Cold War undertone. While the animation steals the show, the story unfortunately never lives up to it's potential. The characters are simply boring, and the bland voice acting make the characters seem even more lifeless. Plus despite being an adult animated film, the plot ends up being simplistic-to-a-fault while the ending is a super-cliche "can't we all just get along" happy ending that seemed too good to be believable.

The animation alone makes the film worth seeing but don't expect the narrative to blow your mind.

Fantastic Planet is a very original animated movie that was made way ahead its time. The Human Race, known as Ohms, live on a distance planet where we are treated as pets. The movie really has some insight on how the human race can be viewed from a different perspective. The movie portrays as somewhat savage, and primitive creatures that also cannot be under estimated. Really interesting movie and worth watching.
Oh my. Wow. This French animation is just crazy. Mini humans kept as pets, such a cool idea. So good.

Trippy animated sci-fi film about humans ruled over by a race of giant blue humanoids and their struggle to survive.  Plays at times like a Twilight Zone episode.  The film is a bit too abrupt to be worthy of all-out admiration.

With beautiful, stylistic hand-drawn animation, extraordinary world building, an admirable attention to detail and such an imaginative, yet thematically sophisticated story, Fantastic Planet is also very dreamlike and strange accompanied by such a great score and phenomenal creature designs. Consequently, this artistic French classic is one of the best that both animation and science fiction have to offer.
A truly original and bizarre animated film. It's a little slow paced, but if you are patient, Fantastic Planet will turn out to be one of the most interesting films you'll ever see.

In the distant future, humanity has been captured by a race of giant blue aliens with mystical powers and removed to a planet where they are kept as pets; one man raised in captivity escapes to join the "wild Oms" and devises a plan for humanity to escape. The Salvador-Dali-meets-Terry-Gilliam-in-space animation and psychedelic soundtrack invite altered viewing, but this is more than JUST a trip; there's a strong sci-fi story here set in a beautifully realized alternate realty.
More interesting than actually good.
An interesting French animation; though the character movement isn't great, some of the scenery and characters are quite impressive.

Vizualno freakish. "if its so surreal and philosophical, then how come the only thing that sticks out for me is an old woman on her death bed with her long grey carrot tits falling into her armpits?" ahahahahahahahahahah

This movie would be a great double feature with Zardoz. This movie hits the mark on its message better than most sci-fi movies, and as much as I enjoy strange movies, sometimes it seems to be strange just for the sake of being strange. Overall, definitely worth seeing.

It meanders around a lot more than it should, given its running time, but this is a spectacular portrait of cultural vastness with all the weight and style necessary to make an impression today; rushed ending aside, the journey their is more than enough to make this a worthy animated endeavor.
Totally bizarre animated film that gets better each time I see it.

On a planet far far away, giants rule over the humanoids and keep them as pets, making them wear collars and staging fights between them for fun. When one of the giants takes in a particular human (known as om's), she brings him everywhere until one day, he runs away. He eventually finds the colony of his own race and they eventually come of with the plan of using their two rockets to try and reach a planet where they may be safe (the fantastic planet). This is one of the most bizarre films I have ever seen, and oddly one of the best films overall that I have ever seen. Made in 1973, it has creepy animation that will be easily acceptable once you realize what you are in for, the voice acting is very impressive, the story is very original, and the conclusion will leave you smiling, if you followed everything that happened. My only complaint is that, even though it is a cartoon, they really push the limits of their PG rating. This is one of the most unique films I have ever seen. "Fantastic Planet" is nothing short of fantastic!
Fantastic Planet has fantastic artwork and scenery...which makes it so aggravating that it also has stale acting, stinted animation, and out of place scenes.
Psycadelic but not enough. I mean, if you have to go down that road at least do it big time! As for the story, "Planet of the Apes" told a similar one 5 years earlier.

Fantastic Planet is a vividly animated parable that is equal parts inventive, otherwordly, and sublime. Taking place in a land populated by psychic giants, the plot focuses on a humanoid who strives to make these creatures realize that his race is a sentient group capable of emotion and deserving of dignity. A jarringly beautiful fable about racism, Fantastic Planet is unique masterwork of art house animation.
a must for every stoner or Tool fan.
A nonsensical, yet original piece of art that captures the imagination and is visually pleasing. Definitely worth a watch.

Definitely a product of its time, "Fantastic Planet" is so obviously aimed at stoners that one feels guilty watching it straight. Between the outer-space setting, the bloopy synthesizer score, the fanciful creatures, the lava-lamp vistas, the emphasis on out-of-body meditation and a host of drug-like rituals, the film practically reeks of marijuana. Head-flick alert! See it with a giggling friend.

At its core, this animated French fable has a familiar theme of two rival tribes coming together as one. The giant Draags are slim, bald and blue, with bulging red eyes and fish-like features. They dominate over their planet's tiny humans (or "Oms," as in "hommes"), either exterminating them like bugs or callously keeping them as childrens' pets (they easily fit in the palm of a Draag's hand). Eventually, an outsider sect of Oms challenges the Draags' rule, possibly dooming both populations. But what's most delightful is not the thin story, but all the whimsical, throwaway images that don't even contribute to the plot. One imagines the screenwriters brainstorming for random elements to add, suggesting "Hey, about a scene with crystals?" "OK, but I have an idea for a monster!" So many surreal snapshots that pop up just once and make a quick exit.

The dull color palette is a minus -- most of the scenery has a similar, salmon-colored tone -- but the one glaring flaw is an inexplicably rushed ending. After 70 minutes of graceful storytelling, the denouement feels like something tossed together on deadline. Wham bam, film over. What?

This movie is so strange and insane, I love it. Very trippy and very expressive. I don't think it has the sense to be pretentious, as it's too off-the-wall crazy to be anything other than one of the weirdest animated films one could see.

As far as visuals are concerned, this may be the most beautiful looking animated film I've ever seen. Thick, vibrant colors fill the screen at every moment, and strange, hand-drawn creatures, walk, wiggle and swoop through every frame, making good on its title's promise. It's an adventure story with a powerful message, a film but primitive and far more advanced than most live-action movies. Perhaps most amazing of all, the setting and characters have no connection to ours or us (although the Oms, admittedly, are perfectly human, physically). The story is concerned with a planet in which giant, blue creatures keep Oms (the human-like people aforementioned) as pets, controlling their environment, food, sleep patterns, clothing, etc. But a group of rebell Oms, of which our central Om eventually becomes a part of, decides to fight back, defending their civil rights and proving their equal intellect. It's a story that certainly has a point to deliver, but that message goes down easy and beautifully. In fact, the images it's delivered with are so beautiful that one digests the message almost distractedly. It's a wonderful piece of art that makes less subtle, less imaginative films of its kind look like wastes of celluloid.
The animation simulates surreal paintings in motion and the plot is disturbingly intriguing. This film could easily have been made by the same aliens it depicts.
Too strange for words. :D
Increbile, strong images, not for weak hearts!
It's visual power lies not in what you immediately see when watching it, but in the associations that take place in your mind after wards.
You have too see this, one of the coolest freakest films I have ever seen. Nothing to compare this too, its awesome.
Everyone should see this, though it probably will go over most peoples' heads.  That's not elitist - the film is pretty damn out there.
Wow they did a lot of drugs in the 70's.. I liked this weird weird movie.
Surreal, magical, weird and melancholic. A great animated ride from the 70's.

French-Czech co-production which may or may not be an exceedingly weird allegory for the Soviet rule in Czechoslovakia last century.  Using some sort of hand-painted cut-outs rather than usual animation techniques, Laloux and his team create a bizarre world of strangely shaped flora and fauna in muted colors wherein some very large blue creatures keep very small human-looking creatures as pets (and exterminate the feral ones as pests).  The proggy soundtrack helps but the denouement is far too rapid (after the slow, sociological build-up).  Still this is out there enough to be worth it.

Taking place in another world where humankind are uncivilized small bug-sized creatures, and the rulers are intelligent giant blue alien creatures, this animated cult trip is the feature debut of Rene Laloux, made in the communist Czechoslovakia. Obviously a lot of references to anti-communism of the time, but still a bizarrely wonderful film. And the music might be the most enduring part, being countlessly sampled by hip hop and electronic artists over the last 20 or so years.
Cool animation, plot, & soundtrack.  This French animation piece from 1973 is a classic.

I don't like praising movies that are totally bizarre just because everyone else is doing it wanting to be all intelligent and 'out of the box', but this movie is genius.
The message is so clear and brilliant. Despite all the futuristic and brain-washing visuals and elements in the movie: I love it.

The trailer scared the bajesus out of me.

Decided to watch this movie after hearing it as a sample in the song "Come on feet" by Quasimoto and this movie was the strangest i have ever seen. Everything about the film including the creepy creatures, sound effects, and story blew my mind!
disturbing, original, creepy,amazing. Must watch, but expect to feel uncomfortable.
This movie has a fantastic argument and some really crazy/awesome animation. Certainly one of my top animated films.
i never wanted to own a copy of a film more. what more can be said really?
Crazy film, would like to see again.
Perhaps the strangest, but certainly the most haunting film I've seen. I saw it once on late night cable in the late 80s and never forgot it.

Where is Barry Bostwick? I see nor hear no Barry Bostwick, yet there is in the cast list, or rather is the cast list apparently. Bizarre, and I mean BIZARRE. 

In any case this is a thoroughly surreal and lysergic movie,that can at times be slightly unsettling. The animation is difficult to describe, especially to someone who hasn't seen this or any of La Loux's other work. The movie clearly has, or would like you to believe it has something important to say about something. Butt those philosophical ambitions are at best only half realized. Leaving you with a visually engrossing movie, with a plot that while interesting also seems anti-climatic if not unfinished.
"Bizarre" just about sums it up. The soundtrack is awesome.

what it says is sometimes baffling, sometimes contrived. What it shows you though is a bizarre, captivating, drug induced, wonderland that will keep you watching regardless of how you feel about the plot or scriptwriting. Not only a statement in forms of social commentary then but also an illustration of a peculiar philosophical and visual outlook.

Though a critique of prejudice is a good premise for a Sci-fi feature, this one fails due partially to it's almost unwatchable animation, and largely due to a story you are told not shown. Far too over-arching narration adds to the worst frame-rated animation to equal a very disappointing cannes winner.
While the film's roughly-drawn, shapeless animation may be stuck in the 70s, its fable is sophisticated and timeless.
Brilliant, strange, surreal, and unsettling.  The plot is almost superfluous, the look of the film is hypnotic.

9.1/10

              I once dreamed that I died and was reborn as a little blue child. I'm sure that dream wasn't brought on by those years watching "The Smurfs", or those times I've watched the recently released "Avatar", but perhaps something I hadn't experienced yet. "Fantastic Planet" happens to be the film that coincidentally reminds me of my dream- or in this case-nightmare. This piece of sheer hallucinogenic brilliance is some of the best French cinema has to offer when it comes to animation; and if you're going to see it, then see it for the surrealistic visuals. But wait, there's also a story going on here as well, and it involves themes of racism, war, and the usual futuristic material that a proper Sci-Fi film should have. "Fantastic Planet" is indeed fantastic, and in a great number of ways. It succeeds miraculously as an animated feature, a tense drama, and a compelling sci-fi film all in one. It doesn't take a good film to do this; it takes a great one. And in my opinion, "Fantastic Planet" is great; in fact, it might just be one of my favorite animated films yet. There's so much genius going on here at once that it's easy to loose track of the real picture set in front of you; but if you can comprehend this brilliant little bugger, then it's one of the best animated acid trips you will ever take. And considering the nigh inexcusable lack of trippy films these days, that's saying a lot. It's a nice piece of adult animation, but I have but one concern, and this particular one goes out to parents. To the parents who are reading; do not let your children watch this film. Chances are it will terrify them because the imagery is often times too frightening and "fantastic" for their age group to either comprehend or withstand. But as they grow, it might be good to expose this kind of stuff to them. It's not "inappropriate" by any means; I just don't want anyone's child to be scarred for life after watching stuff like this at a young age. It may be animated, but that does not mean it's for kids. If you were to ask me, I actually find something oddly charming about adult animated films; and perhaps it rests in their unique layers of complexity. "Fantastic Planet" is some damn good animation. And considering what can be done in animation, there's reason to see the thing as it is.

        We set the scene on a planet inhabited by humanoid blue people called Draags, and another species of smaller humanoid beings called Oms. The two species live in harmony for quite some time; with the Draags often treating the tamed Oms as their pets while the Oms just go along with it. However, there are stray Oms, and they are starting a rebellion against the mere existence of the Draags. And these little guys are uncommonly feisty; in spite of their size. So the film is about a war; I'll admit that. But it's also about a central character, who is- in this case- a little boy who grows up as a tamed Om. The boy escapes his alien captors and joins a group of rebellious Om; all who share the same dream of freedom. He gets caught up in the middle of this grand war; and the film essentially builds itself around the themes of warfare and the future. The war depicting in this film mimics that of the Cold War, while the sci-fi themes are in plain sight. But this is no ordinary animated feature; it uses its visuals and plot to tell its story. You can look at the visuals and envision a plot on its own, or you can listen to the story being told. I did both; and got a lot out of this masterpiece. There's a lot of artistic design that went into the story and the visuals; and each good aspect makes "Fantastic Planet" all the more fantastic. It's one of the best adult animated films ever made; and one of the more memorable films of the 1970's. Some think that it has lost its spark, but I disagree. I think that "Fantastic Planet"- and its themes- is very much alive. It's for those who can accept it as art.

       Sadly, there is not much to say about the voice cast of the film. There are not enough voice actors that should be considered note-worthy; although that does not mean they are bad. The film's voice cast sounds very good, and the only name I can find out of the entire cast- as of now- is Barry Bostwick. But I suppose this film is not about the cast; it's about the vision that has been created. That is what you should be paying attention to here; not so much the talents involved behind the voices of each character. Speaking of which, the characters in this film are very well developed. Despite the absence of the voice cast's notability, that's good enough for me.

         This is what I want when I hear "great animated film". Sure, Pixar is nice. In fact, Pixar is pretty great. But they're a big, modern animated company; while "Fantastic Planet" is a little, "old" animated feature. It's not the kind of animated film that could be made anymore, because good or not, most of them use a lot of dialogue. This one in particular is like "2001" squeezed just a little bit beyond the one hour mark. The film is short- even for an animated film- but yet it tells a delicate story and has spectacular visuals. The film feels surreal, trippy, and all-around awesome. I have seen great French films; and I have also seen great animated films from France. But this one is one of the best; not only from its year or its decade, but also from French cinema alike. I will indeed treasure this film in some way or form. The visual style is revolutionary to me, and I'll recognize it from time-to-time. I will be recommending this work of art to many people; just not young children, for this is a piece of animation that was not made for them. Some will say that "Fantastic Planet" is a recommended "family viewing". Do not listen to these people; "Fantastic Planet" should only be watched by intelligent minds belonging to intelligent people. It's doubtful that the whole family will have that kind of mind, but if they do, then good for them; this film is one of the whole crowd. But you get my point; this is an intelligent and complex work of science fiction filmmaking. I was very entertained by the imagery, the story-telling, and the thematic elements alike.

        I do not know why a film as great as this was forgotten by so many. Perhaps it was not marketed correctly, or perhaps the critical reception was divided. This animated film remains daring even to this day, but that's part of why I enjoyed it so much. There's a lot to look at and think about here; and how can you resist a film which has that kind of stuff in it? This film is very artistic, never explicit, but never "kiddish" either. It's animation for the grown-ups, and there's something I admire about that. But alas, this film cannot be put into words. It's the kind of surrealistic, cinematic acid trip that you need to experience for yourself; regardless of who you are. This film will please sci-fi and animation fans alike; and if you can dig it, then you can love it as well. And yes, I do love "Fantastic Planet". I love it very much. So much animation clichés are non-existent here, and this is a film which wants to create animated art at any cost. The film will be intense, thematic, and complex whether we like it or not. Kids will run under the covers while the parents will remain fascinated. I think that this film is fairly spell-binding; or at least enough so that adults will like it or at least love it. You can say what you want about the film, but there's something ominous and savage about "Fantastic Planet" that I can't quite put my finger on. Strangely enough, that's kind of why I love it; because I don't fully understand it. I guess you don't need to understand this one completely to enjoy it as much as I did. But you sure need to enjoy it for starters. Chances are you will.

Seeing as how none of my friends have reviewed this film yet, I will be the first to say that Fantastic Planet is one of the underappreciated gems of cinema I have seen in my lifetime.
It was very under the radar in its original release, and it has faded into obscurity over the years. Now is the perfect time to discover it.

The political and social commentary is clearly defined, and the music is chilling to the overall atmosphere. The visuals are so simplistic and yet very expressive; capturing every emotion and feeling of horror in the film. 

Fantastic Planet is now among my favorite animated films. Since very few of you may have seen it, I strongly recommend checking it out.

A unique animated work that effectively creatures a believable alien world. The simplistic plot may be heavy on allegory, and the ending is pretty abrupt - but the images are so original and intriguing, the bizarre atmosphere is enough to make it a very special work of art.

This movie is quite amazing. First it's made in a very special way in a very weird planet with disturbing creatures. Secondly it shows us an idea about our future how the human will become an animal for those weird blue guys who looks like extraterrestrials. I think this movie is really cool and deserves many prizes.
ive already reviewd this , its awsome!!  ocasionaly cheesy but really good surealist ideas!! take that avatar!!!!

As much as I love surrealism, this one didn't quite work for me.  It attempted to have a coherent plot, but in the end, I think that hurt "Fantastic Planet," due to some sizable plot holes.  Why did the abandoned rocket factory still have power?  How did shooting giant, dancing statues with a laser render the Traags blind?  Your guess is as good as mine.  I'm not saying it should have gone the same route as "Cat Soup," where very little is clear at all, but if the writer/director wanted a believable plot, then they should have tended to the holes.

Then there's the pseudo-science babbling that crops up occasionally.  I appreciate the attempt to flesh out the world, but when you're doing it with entirely nonsensical terms, it means nothing.  "Gaggfins emerge on the fejiner every twelve luopis, but lack the quintl to peif a skwerly emulsion" makes about as much sense as a lot of the attempts to expound upon the world in this film.  True, there are often accompanying pictures, but they rarely help illuminate things all that much.

On that note however, I rather liked the animation in this film.  Somewhat reminiscent of the style found in "Monty Python's Flying Circus," it is by turns simplistic and deceptively detailed, and always bizarre.  "Fantastic Planet" is a visual feast, that won't disappoint, if you have a taste for the surreal, and if you can forgive the lax writing.
I'm not really sure how I feel about this one yet. I love the animation style. It was a bit hard to follow. Pretty trippy. Interesting French film, pretty bizarre. Hahahs.
The oddest film I've ever seen.  I was tripping balls.

One of the most consistently strange films ever made... a work of frenziedly male - adolescent, even - imagination: a hotchpotch of SF bandes dessinees, the music (and album covers) of Focus and Yes, and doubtless several psychotropic substances to boot. Its wilder, crueller flourishes clearly stuck with Svankmajer and Gilliam, to name but two; viewed today, it would seem to contain at least as much diverting kitsch as genuine artistry, though those visuals will be a boon for hipster projectionists at retro club nights, and promoters may wish to retain Alain Goraguer's score, too, coming in as it does equidistant between prog rock and the accompaniment to any European porno movie of the period.

This is such a mundane  but with outer truly ODD outerwordly elements..very unique, and the quality about it makes you REALLY pay attention and want more. Though I attempted watching this a multitude of times, I could never finish to the end. The large vocabulary that I thought I would have to look up, wasnt relevant to the story, just the basis of Oms (humans) versus the Traag(alien higher intellect life form) It wasnt as long as I thought it would be.But its comical to see how small and weak humans can soon be one day.

The bare bones plot is pretty straightforward.  Weird, but straightforward.  However, the beautifully strange visuals (kind've like the animated segments from Monty Python), and wonderfully bizzare creatures turn it into the acid trip that it is.  A strangely hypnotic and wonderfully original film.

This french curio has a similiar story to Battle Feild Earth. However don't let that put you off because in quality the two films are miles apart. Although the animation feels dated in comparison to its modern equivalant it still has a genuine charm and beauty. With its LSD and Dali inspired dream scapes, this sureal and haunting film is certainly worth a watch.
There's a lot in "The Fantastic Planet" that I admire and respect, but I just can't find it in myself to recommend a film as bizarre and strange as this.

I remember seeing this a long, long, long time ago when I was a kid and I caught up with it recently and it is still as weird now as it was then. Very simple animation but full of imagination and weird concepts.
world where humans are kept as pets of large blue giants.  loved the old school animation and the surrealism of this.  odd but fun to watch

very fond of this movie. surreal. psychedelic. i became very interested in the back story of the Draags and their culture. 
It's not in 3d, but the visuals were still exceptional. 

the creatures in this film are drawn creatively and the whole movie has this element of innocence and cuteness, even though its pretty dark. 

OH
and the soundtrack is awesome, the film works very well without dialogue.
