1973.  amazing. impossible to overstate weirdness. almost perfect. fantastic.
The Fall of Man...in space.

I give this thenthrousand septembudunuaries out of a possible sixtellionsensdoui. 

The funcktsaboulificitations (that's a Belshmar word for 'production values') may be somewhat lowfunctual, the animatshunsaneefidobulous is astonishing, and lends itself well to the flemskintuinarious-sables.

If you have the means, see this with saturn-floriencino-sauce for best effect. This story is actually one told to Agent Maxter Sphinxton, on the eve of the all-star explosion when he was a young Spantisuxion.

The story was brilliant, for he coveted it all the way through the Garbingshurious Galaxy, all the way to McEarth (McDonald's bought out the rights to the name of our planet in the year 5670a-).

It truly is a fantastic talshanisbootiousflem, and I absolute highly recommondiflys this varbinshinsurance.

Actually, the release date was 1973....
Anyway, my first memory of this movie was when I was quite young (maybe 7?) and walking in on the beginning of it while my grandfather was watching it.  It creeped me out, but fascinated me.  And finally, after all these years, I got to watch it.
It's terrifying.  Not in a 'stabs-and-gore-shrieking-music' kind of way, but in that if and when you start to relate to the protagonist (and it happens quickly), you feel a cold chill wind through your body.  The writing and characters are wonderfully crafted, and damn if you can't be charmed by that prog-funk (Thanks Doug) soundtrack.
Thankfully this movie also doesn't overstay it's welcome ending at a reasonable 70 minutes.
Fantastic Planet is a psychedelic science fiction piece complete with a social agenda and progressive funk soundtrack.
Turn the color all the way up on your TV, eat some mushrooms and prepare for the most tripest experience since the last time you watched it sober.
A 1973 (and not 1999)  animated science fiction film directed by RenÃ© Laloux.Written by RenÃ© Laloux and Roland Topor based on Stefan Wul's novel Oms en sÃ©rie.
This is the movie you watch high. Very high. Very visually stimulating like an animated Salvador Dali painting.
Some great visuals and some bizzare creations on display here, full of imagination
Avatar for the arthouse.

Giant blue aliens on a world primarily concerned with transcendental meditation enthusiasm keep humans as pets. 

Concern grows over the increasing numbers of wild humans that "steal", and as it is wondered how much intelligence they really possess they start to show alarming signs of understanding the world, prompting calls for their eradication. 

Animation techniques are dated in this one, but there still manages to be some eye-catching environments and creature designs.

Emotionally flat at times, it alternately engages and disengages, leaving the viewer with the feeling of oddness. 

I admire the attempt more than its execution, though consideration for 1970s technology must be held. It was an interesting piece to watch with some detachment.
Very cool, trippy French animated feature! Political and social undertones are definitely felt throughout, and the film can be enjoyed both knowing about these issues or w/o them!

On a distant planet, humans are called Oms and are the pets of giant blue creatures where a week of their time is a years worth for a human.  One of these human pets escapes into the wild with the teaching technology that the giant blue aliens use.  He runs into a pack of wild Oms and starts teaching them of the ways of the giant blue aliens.
It's an interesting movie and visually it isn't like anything I've ever seen before.  Sci-fi fans should enjoy it.
this movie is NOT 1999 you cowards

(*** 1/2): Thumbs Up

A strange and surreal animated film that reminded me a lot of those old Heavy Metal magazines.
Some of the best atmospheric movie music you'll ever hear.
Totally bizarre film.  The animation was interesting but some of the story elements weren't very clear and some of the sound effects were annoying.
Bizarre sci-fi ... wild, cruel... a nice travel into a weird planet, where humans are called Oms and they're wild animals or pets for the main creaturs who rules the planet. I love it
the art style feels a bit dated, but that's the only complaint i have.  a wonderfully strange story about a planet where humans are the ants instead.

Such a dreamy movie .. was great fun especially the ending. The imagery was awesome (given the fact that its early 1970s) and intriguing and you can't help but cheer as the humans rebel :D
Of course it makes you wanna think about how we treat those that we think are lesser than us but I didn't see much of anything resembling a political parallel though it might've very well have been.
Increbile, strong images, not for weak hearts!

I thought this was going to be way weirder and more experimental than it was. But I thought it was perfectly engaging animated film in which human beings are at best pets if not pests in a planet ruled by giant intellectual beings known as Draags. There are tons of weird psychedelic and surreal visuals. I see this as being remade with "Avatar" technology.
Watch it in the original French, with English subtitles if needed. Much better that way.
I'm an ignorant savage who doesn't understand great art when I see it. Got to admit that I like the message in the end, though. Also, I'm probably a little traumatized right now.
Finally saw this one. Good animation, interesting story and very groovy music. I wonder if the French dialogue differs substantially from the English language track.

Fantastic Planet will likely fascinate you or give you nightmares.  Either way, this imaginative animated film from Rene Laloux.  This is an odd sci-fi film about the Traags who keep human-like Oms as pets.  The oppressed Oms begin an uprising.  Utterly unique drawn in soft pastel colors, Fantastic Planet is a truly bizarre piece of filmmaking; and certainly one that needs to be viewed.

What a beautiful film. The mood evoked by this surreal, superbly illustrated dance among Dali and Bosch sceneries will not soon leave you. That the plot is a mere thread detracts nothing from this film; the real story is taking place in your own subconscious as you watch an environment unfolding in progressively beautiful layers, revealing a dreamscape at once beautifully alien and yet wierdly familiar. It will become an old favorite right away.
"Oh, they're flying into a Roger Dean album cover!"  "They're very into 'Yes' on this planet."

first off theirs a reason why they call it fantastic planet (aka PLANET MUTHA FU*KER!!--jks) great movie!!  fantastic animation!!!  in your sad faces diseny!! in your pixeld faces pixar and so on! its got amazing random motion filled bacground settings!  -----flash back--- i was young and haning out in a myers store wen i first caught a glimps at this strange video cassete!  my mother took one look at it and sayd that looks weird! later i was my good freind watching it on tv being sucked into its story and ideas!  years later i saw it and wow!!  it blew me away!  im a sucker for films with blue girls!! ---so anyway in your conformist faces hollywood!!  watch it you om!!
Fantastic, in a French sorta way, so more like halfway between "fantastic" and "meh," which is still pretty good.  Certainly weird as hell anyway, and you gotta love it for that.

This is a trippy piece of movie. The limited animation combined with the disturbing surreal art style makes me come to the realization that with there are aliens out there in the universe, we're f&@#$%!
Fascinating. One of the most imaginative animations I've ever seen. Hard to believe this was made in 1973.
if its so surreal and philosophical, then how come the only thing that sticks out for me is an old woman on her death bed with her long grey carrot tits falling into her armpits?

They don't make them like this anymore and they didn't really even make them like this back then. It's premodern postmodern in the tradition of "weird for the sake of weird", but it nonetheless manages to hold together pretty well. It's just coherent enough to be enjoyable even in a drug-free environment. It won't teach you anything valuable, but watching it won't make you stupider. either; and in the world of film that puts it a cut above the rest.
An oddity to be sure, but it's unique animation and bold style help overcome the fact that it hasn't aged amazingly (not terribly aged, but def shows age a bit)

this film deserves more than a one sentence review. but if I must:
the most socially aware animated film ever made, and the greatest story in an animated film i've ever seen.

One of the best animated films Ive ever seen: simply put this film puts life into perspective with an exceptional touch. 

For a film that dates more than 30 years old; this visually stunning film still holds up amazingly well, its damn near perfect in my book. Fantastic Planet tells the story of a race of human-like people called Oms, who are dominated by giant beings called Draags, who are by comparison ten times bigger than the Oms. The story is pretty straight forward actually, which in a film like this, is good, as it allows the mind plenty of time to soak up the surreal visuals. The whole film is completely engrossing, preferring to stay in the realm of grotesquely odd, rather than throw complicated themes at you. This little gem is highly recommended for anyone who remotely likes animation and a must-see for anyone interested in a brilliant other worldly film. One of the many films that you push aside and tell yourself youll eventually see; this one needs to come to the forefront of your need to see list.
Odd little movie. Has a lot of things to say, but doesnt focus on that and rather tries to be more entertaining than it needs to be.
well worth the wait. next time i watch it i should probably be on acid.

Not quite as powerful now as it must have been when it first come around, La Planete Sauvage is a unique veiwing experience.  Harking back through cinema's surrealists there's a strong Dali, Magritte and Gilliam influence throughout lifting this above the less cerebral imagery of something like The Yellow Submarine.  Less trippy and more artistically conscious I guess.

The story itself isn't that interesting except when put against the backdrop of the continued Russian presence in Czechoslovakia, post-Prague uprising.  However the scenery is laden with undefined symbolism which mean the relatively flat animation doesn't grate too much.  So even if there's a lessened impact it is an interesting piece of work, especially when put alongside the production line of today's cgi animated industry.

Pretty much everything you should want from good sci-fi is evident in this film but it's not fully realised and a little diluted over the running time. That said, it's still a very thought-provoking and mostly entertaining film if a little dry. 

Personal enjoyment: 7/10
Actual quality as a film: 7/10

- lack of depth in characters
- abrupt ending
+ animation
+ some ideas throughout the story
Obviously bizarre, but one of the few films I've ever seen that really delves into the true nature of power.

Wizards and Heavy Metal are usually the two films brought up when looking back at retro adult-aimed animated fare, but this is better than either of them. This intoxicating Czech/French production feels like the child of Pink Floyd and Frank Herbert, and backs up it's creepy visuals with an intriguing story. The narration is unnecessary and there is a bit of suspension of disbelief needed near the climax, but I doubt you won't walk away from this film pleased. It's easy to see why hip-hop producer Madlib likes this movie so much.
Very weird and strange film. I have no idea what happened. So I stopped watching it.

The artwork is stunning, and story line an original masterpiece. The plotline of this story is simple. I liked this movie because it makes you think. If you like sci-fi/fantasy films, you'll enjoy this movie.
The bastard child of Dr. Seuss and Salvador Dali. I can dig it.

A painfully obviously 1970s French animated film about large blue aliens and the humans they keep as pets which they call "Oms." The story focuses on one human who is kept as a pet by a young alien and involves the human in everything including the alien's learning sessions. One day the human escapes with a learning device and comes upon a bunch of "savage" humans who have lived in hiding for a long time. At first rejected because of the knowledge he brings with him, the knowledge is soon embraced in order to unite against the aliens and their cyclical extermination of escaped humans. If you like this style of surreal animation its worth a watch, but it seems to have been drawn out in order to make it feature length; should have been condensed.
One of my all time favorites with music by Alain Goraguer. Watch it!

Incredibly insightful and inspirational work of art. This film really represents everything that is wrong with science fiction films today. Thank goodness that we have people, such as the makers of FANTASTIC PLANET, that will always be able to leave us spellbound by their work. This film is simply a pure work of art that should be required viewing by everyone on the face of the earth.

Sui Generis
Savage marionette world
Ecology-vex

I never want to keep a pet or put anything on a leash ever again! This movie is original, beautiful, sad, trippy, and humans are knocked down off their pedestal. It had all of the glorious things I look for in a movie. In short, it blew my fucking mind.

It's a metaphoric morality tale that is very trippy.  Still, even for the early 1970s, Fantastic Planet has poor production value.  Yeah, I know it's from Czechoslovakia, but I still have standards. The animation is generated from crude line drawings (think midway between the Yellow Submarine or Monty Python's Flying Circus animation in terms of quality).  It's score is made up of synthesizer-sounding pops and hisses along with echoey, haunting melodies.  There's a somber tone and a slow pace as we follow a the human main character from captivity to freedom to rebellion.  The characters, except for the main character and his captor, are not very fleshed out.  I can't even get behind the hero very strongly, as he is also a narrator, giving incessant voice-over exposition throughout the film.  
I think I got a simple message out of it: If you mistreat and abuse another race or ethnic group that you perceive as inferior, when in fact they are of equal value and intelligence, they will eventually learn how to rise up against you.  And when they do, they may make peace so everyone can coexist, but there will be a lot of death along the way if this path of war is taken.  It's a nice message for sure, but Fantastic Planet might give you strange dreams from all the grotesque and surreal creatures inhabiting its world.

Futuristic, surreal Hippie fantasy about meditating aliens who keep humanoids as pets. aprupt ending.
(Release date is 1973, not 99 like it says here)
Very much of its time stinker

French director RenÃ© Laloux again, this film is always more appreciated than Gandahar, but I like both! 
This one's also got beautiful images. And it's Laloux first Sci-Fi full-length film. Maybe the "plus" is the music by Alain Goraguer! If you're a fan of music, it has to be seen just for the soundtrack!!!
A fine adventure story.
By far the weirdest looking animated movie I've ever seen. It was like watching a feature length Terry Gilliam animation. It was interesting to say the least.
This is why I love animated movies!

Talk about a mind fuck. The animations are vary simplistic but artistic at the same time. The use of music as sound effects is clever and it has an interesting story line. Humans are compared to common vermin on an alien planet and are treated much like rats. They are kept as pets however, things change quickly as the plot develops!
Strange animated movie with giant blue aliens keeping humans as pets. Fairly short too - a little over an hour. Intriguing movie - watch it if you can find it.
Amazing 70s animation and music telling one scary fucking story (to me, at least.) Watch it if you can!
A thinking person's story.Surreal animation.Totally awesome.

70's Surreal and philosophical animation about a future world where man is a tiny savage species amongst the more cerebral big blue people, and is treated accordingly as toys and/or pests. Fantastic :-)
Simple production but pretty good story.  Although the ending felt a little out of place, like there was 30 minutes missing.  The production may not be for everyone but it is worth watching.
Gonzo French animated film about aliens that keep humans as pets.

Couldn't pull my eyes away from this movie.  So many original ideas make this an animated story that can't be beat. And then at the end when I read that it was based on the Soviet occupation of Czech Republic, my mind blew up all over the tv.
The feeling of this animated film is pure magic. The music by Alain Goraguer is simply unforgettable.
A very strange and bizzare movie, wonderful ideas and really out there sound design. Animation is a little crude, but works.

A wonderfully animated film, The Fantastic Planet offers up a very imaginative world where tiny humans known as Oms are kept by giant blue space aliens known as Draags. We follow the story through a single Om named Terr who is adopted as a pet as a young boy after his mother dies and becomes pet to a young Draags female. Terr is smart for an Om and learns much of Draag culture and education until he reaches a point he can't learn anymore. At this point Terr escapes his captivity and ventures out into the free world only to discover a society of primitive, free Oms that live in fear of each other and the Draags. The film has powerful political overtones but told through such an imaginative way. The animation, music and voice acting is very calming and surreal. I remember as a kid this movie used to come on late night cable access the movie was so soothing it would help me fall asleep.
I can't quite put my finger on this one. Is it good? Entertaining? Artistic? INTERESTING? I think it just tries to be bizarre for the sake of being bizarre. At least it does a great job of it.
Every wanted to hallucinate without actually taking any drugs?

disturbing? beautiful? fantastic? thought-provoking? unsettling? weird as all hell?
yes.

i must say though, the ending was a little anti-climatic for me. how was the peace achieved?

Without a doubt one of my favorite animated films ever. It's a great sci-fi story. The music works perfectly for the picture. The animation style is completely unique and beautiful. Watch it and I promise it will be different then anything you've seen before.
Something i have never seen before. plus the story gets you thinking about we treat some of our smallest animals
I love this.  Any still frame could be a work of art.  And I looove all the surreal creatures and plants.

A beautiful relic from the days when intellectuals weren't afraid of a little LSD.  Even if sci-fi isn't your thing, this is still worth watching because it's more about surrealism than anything else.  Rene Laloux and Roland Topor (the guy who, among other things, wrote the novel that Roman Polanski adapted to make "The Tenant") cook up a story about 50-foot-tall space aliens who make humans their pets. A crack team of Czechoslovakian animators make the whole thing look like a bunch of De Chirico paintings.  Add a very 1973 soundtrack with the guitarist flooring the wah-wah and you've got a surprisingly excellent film.

-really great and original animated film.  awesome concept
-great soundtrack- 70s psychedelic fusion
-I was on board until the last 15 minutes or so and then it got just too far fetched/out of hand

The psychedelic 60's score works very well with the gorgeous, trippy animation. In its animation style, this movie is sui generis, even though the imagery, which owes much to Hieronymous Bosch, is echoed in some other animated films. The plot is lacking, making this just pretty wallpaper, unfortunately. The netflix label tells me its some sort of parable "based on the Soviet occupation of the Czech Republic," but unless the Czech are thirty feet tall and use meditation to travel to the moon to have weird alien sex and nobody told me, I'm not seeing the metaphor. Recommended for students of animation technique, but not essential as a film.

A truly overlooked masterpiece in animation history. This forgotten treasure from French director Rene LaLoux is available on DVD and if it's themes of rebellion don't resonate with you, surely it's eye-melting visuals will fire your imagination!
"Fantastic Planet" is an interesting mix of surrealism and humanism.
A major piece of animation history.

Eerie, meditative and surreal! The animation may not be that fluent, but it only adds to the charm of the film. It makes it feel like it's more of a collage of surreal images, than a regular animated movie. 
The soundtrack has a mystical edge to it, and really helps to carry the story of the film. However, it must be said the story is simple, but it is told in a lucidly beautiful way, which gives the philosophical concepts it explores great emotional poignancy. To the aliens of this strange planet, humans are mere toys, kind of like insects are to us (the aliens and the humans in the films, share the same anatomic proportional ratio, as humans and insects). The film does not do the misstake of telling the film entirely from the point of view of the humans, but start of from the alien point of view, where it really makes us understand, even intimate how insignificant humans seem to the aliens.

ABSURD!!!! This is by far one of the weirdest movies I have ever seen. That is somewhat its strength and weakness. The vision, the art, the music, all so stunningly beautiful. Yet there is supposed to be some form of metaphor or symbolism, but we get so lost in it that we forget the point and just accept it as a simple story. But this is definitely a movie to see before you die, even if it clearly isn't the best.
A psychedelic and philosophical animated film that blows my mind even when I'm completely sober.

I LOVE the animation- not so much the choppiness, but the art is absolutely mind-blowing. The story is a little locked in its time (early seventies) and the ending is a bit abrupt, but it manages to hold the viewer's interest for the most part. But the art- whoo-ee!

Wow that was superiorreality(surreal)!

The music is groundbreaking even by today's standards and the plot is so deeply rooted in metaphor and history, it's almost a universal mental image.
